awd_abstract_narration:
The goal of this CAREER proposal is to develop a comprehensive data analytics framework for distribution grids, engage students in the exciting field of energy engineering, and advance education on distribution systems. To accomplish any meaningful grid-wide optimization task, the distribution system operator will need to precisely know the power consumed or generated at every node, the line and transformer parameters, and the topology of the grid. However currently, limited instrumentation and their sheer size render power distribution grids unobservable in general. To complement the smart metering and grid sensing infrastructure, the novel technique of grid probing is introduced here. Grid probing can be accomplished by commanding smart inverters residing at a subset of nodes to intentionally yet instantaneously perturb their power injections. Actuating the networked physical system and subsequently sensing the incurred voltages at metered nodes can unveil non-metered loads and network topologies. The original and potentially transformative idea of engaging smart inverters outside their intended control functionality pioneers new grid data analytics. This program goes beyond probing and maps the observability limits by processing smart meter data too. Contemporary optimization schemes together with their real-time and decentralized variants will deal with streaming and spatially incomplete voltage and power injection data collected at large-scale unbalanced distribution networks.

On the broader impact, this program lies at the nexus of power systems, nonlinear system identification, and statistical learning; advances our understanding of unique patterns in grid data; and discovers novel uses for inverters in grid monitoring and control. Enhancing situational awareness in distribution grids benefits society by enabling the efficient and reliable integration of distributed renewable energy, electric vehicles, and customer participation. The expected benefits to industry are cutting-edge grid analytics solutions, advanced asset management, and value added for inverters and smart meters. The proposed activities bring about a potentially transformative paradigm for grid data processing, neatly integrated with educational and outreach objectives. The program reaches pre-college female students through hands-on learning activities and collaborative app-based games on electric grids. It also involves undergraduate research and continues our outreach to undergraduate students through visits to residential communities.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_div_long_name: Division of Electrical, Communications and Cyber Systems

inst.inst_name: Virginia Polytechnic Institute and State University

por.por_cntn:
Distributed energy resources (DERs), such as electric vehicles, photovoltaics, and batteries), are interfaced with the main electric grid through inverters. In addition to their main functionality of energy conversion, inverters are also being used for grid optimization and control. Adding grid monitoring as a third functionality for smart inverters has been the significant contribution of this project. The key idea is to perturb inverter outputs intentionally, collect the grid's voltage response, and process these actively collected data to learn useful grid information, such as non-metered electric loads and network topologies. The research outcomes are summarized below:

 

1) Inverter probing for estimating loads: Assuming the grid topology is known, we have: i) developed sufficient conditions for the placement of inverters to ensure identifiability of non-metered loads; ii) devised solvers to process noisy data; and c) designed inverter sequences that are physically implementable and compliant with network constraints.

 

2) Inverter probing for topology identification: If the grid topology is not (entirely) known, we have: i) developed sufficient conditions for the placement of inverters to ensure topology identifiability; ii) devised a comprehensive suite of methods for grid topology detection and identification using probing data offering varying levels of complexity-optimality trade-off, including mixed-integer models, convex programs, and graph-based algorithms; and iii) characterized the benefit of collecting voltage data at all buses rather than only the probed buses.

 

3) Inverter optimization and control: For decentralized operation, we have designed optimal inverter control rules using optimization and machine learning tools, such as kernel-based learning and deep neural networks. Some rules have been designed jointly with topology reconfiguration tasks to support grid recovery from extreme weather events. To expedite centralized operation and planning with high penetration of DERs, we have expedited the solution of optimal power flow (OPF) optimization problems, leveraging advances from multiparametric programming and incorporating OPF sensitivities into deep neural network models.

 

4) Capturing DER flexibility for energy market participation: How can we optimally learn and describe the flexibility for active power dispatch of an aggregator, while complying with the shapes of feasible sets prespecified by a wholesale electricity market? To address this task, we have developed a data-based methodology to assist aggregators in handling heterogeneous types of DERs characterized by increased uncertainty and non-convex models.

 

The project outcomes in terms of broader impacts are summarized next:

 

1) This project partially funded six graduate research assistants who now excel in academia and industry.

 

2) Dissemination: Research findings were communicated to academia and industry through 50 events, including invited seminars, webinars, and tutorials.

 

3) Outreach to 1,300+ pre-college and undergraduate students through more than 20 activities:

 

a) Ten seminars to undergraduate students on smart grids and career opportunities, some of which targeted audiences from under-served and under-represented groups, such as female, African American, and first-generation college students.

 

b) Five visits to undergraduate residential communities. These faculty visits constitute an excellent opportunity for first-year students to interact with faculty personally and bounce off their career plans.

 

c) Summer onboarding camp and lunches with incoming VT students from under-represented groups.

 

d) Hands-on lab activities to 80 middle-school students at the power systems lab.

 

e) Two discussion panels on career opportunities in STEM with 30 young high-school women from the US and abroad, and 60 high school African American students.


Last Modified: 12/21/2023
Modified by: Vassilis Kekatos

Distributed energy resources (DERs), such as electric vehicles, photovoltaics, and batteries), are interfaced with the main electric grid through inverters. In addition to their main functionality of energy conversion, inverters are also being used for grid optimization and control. Adding grid monitoring as a third functionality for smart inverters has been the significant contribution of this project. The key idea is to perturb inverter outputs intentionally, collect the grid's voltage response, and process these actively collected data to learn useful grid information, such as non-metered electric loads and network topologies. The research outcomes are summarized below:





1) Inverter probing for estimating loads:Assuming the grid topology is known, we have:i)developed sufficient conditions for the placement of inverters to ensure identifiability of non-metered loads;ii)devised solvers to process noisy data; andc)designed inverter sequences that are physically implementable and compliant with network constraints.





2) Inverter probing for topology identification:If the grid topology is not (entirely) known, we have:i)developed sufficient conditions for the placement of inverters to ensure topology identifiability;ii)devised a comprehensive suite of methods for grid topology detection and identification using probing data offering varying levels of complexity-optimality trade-off, including mixed-integer models, convex programs, and graph-based algorithms; andiii)characterized the benefit of collecting voltage data at all buses rather than only the probed buses.

Some rules have been designed jointly with topology reconfiguration tasks to support grid recovery from extreme weather events. To expedite centralized operation and planning with high penetration of DERs, we have expedited the solution of optimal power flow (OPF) optimization problems, leveraging advances from multiparametric programming and incorporating OPF sensitivities into deep neural network models.





4) Capturing DER flexibility for energy market participation:How can we optimally learn and describe the flexibility for active power dispatch of an aggregator, while complying with the shapes of feasible sets prespecified by a wholesale electricity market? To address this task, we have developed a data-based methodology to assist aggregators in handling heterogeneous types of DERs characterized by increased uncertainty and non-convex models.





The project outcomes in terms of broader impacts are summarized next:





1) This project partially funded six graduate research assistants who now excel in academia and industry.





2) Dissemination:Research findings were communicated to academia and industry through 50 events, including invited seminars, webinars, and tutorials.





3) Outreachto 1,300+ pre-college and undergraduate students through more than 20 activities:





a) Ten seminars to undergraduate studentson smart grids and career opportunities, some of which targeted audiences from under-served and under-represented groups, such as female, African American, and first-generation college students.
